    Scraping USADA sanctions

    scraping-usada-sanctions.Rmd

    Packages:

    library(polite)
library(dopingdata)
library(robotstxt)
options(robotstxt_warn = FALSE)

    USADA sanction data

    The data I’ll be downloading comes from USADA sanctions table.

    Use your manners

    Because this package is built on top of the efforts of the fine people who collected, organized, and shared their data, we’re going to use the polite package for harvesting the HTML tables.

    To install this package, run the code below:

    devtools::install_github("dmi3kno/polite")
library(polite)

    polite has many options for ethically scraping data (check out the package website for more information), but I’ve chosen to follow the handy polite template:

    polite::use_manners()

    Check robots.txt

    I’ll check the robots.txt file before scraping the website:

    # retrieval
rtxt <- robotstxt::robotstxt(domain = "https://www.usada.org/")

# printing
rtxt$check(
  # check permissions 
  paths = c("testing/", 
            "testing/results/", 
            "testing/results/sanctions/"),
  # bots
  bot   = "*"
)
#> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE

    All three paths are TRUE, but I will also check the domain with robotstxt::get_robotstxt():

    rt <- robotstxt::get_robotstxt(
  domain = "https://www.usada.org/testing/results/sanctions/")
# printing
cat(rt[1])
#> # robots.txt overwrite by: on_suspect_content
#> 
#> User-agent: *
#> Allow: /

    I can see the Allow: / configuration gives us access to download the data.

    Scraping with polite and rvest

    Below are the steps used to scrape the sanctions table:

    usada_url = "https://www.usada.org/testing/results/sanctions/"
usada_nodes <- polite::bow(usada_url) |> 
  polite::scrape() |> 
  rvest::html_nodes("table") 
usada_sanctions_raw <- rvest::html_table(usada_nodes[[1]])

    Exporting raw data

    Some common tasks (like exporting the raw data as a .csv file into a date-stamped folder and file) have been wrapped in functions:

    export_data(
  x = usada_sanctions_raw, 
  path = "../dev")
#> Exporting data: ../dev/2023-12-19/2023-12-19-usada_sanctions_raw.csv
#> Raw data successfully exported!

    There’s also an export_extdata() function if you’re storing the data in a package:

    export_extdata(
  x = usada_sanctions_raw, 
  path = "dev", 
  raw = TRUE)
#> Exporting raw data: usada_sanctions_raw.csv
#> Raw data successfully exported!
    dir("../inst/extdata/", recursive = TRUE)
#> [1] "raw/2023-12-18/usada_raw.csv"             
#> [2] "raw/2023-12-19/2023-12-19-tidy_sports.csv"
#> [3] "raw/2023-12-19/2023-12-19-usada_dates.csv"

    What does the raw data look like?

    usada_sanctions_raw <- read.csv("../dev/2023-12-19/2023-12-19-usada_sanctions_raw.csv")
str(usada_sanctions_raw)
#> 'data.frame':    937 obs. of  5 variables:
#>  $ Athlete           : chr  "Rodriguez, Daniel" "Park, Mariah" "Frey, John" "Jha, Kanak" ...
#>  $ Sport             : chr  "Mixed Martial Arts" "Weightlifting" "Cycling" "Table Tennis" ...
#>  $ Substance.Reason  : chr  "Ostarine; LGD-4033" "Chlorthalidone" "Non-Analytical: Refusal to Submit to Sample Collection" "Non-Analytical: 3 Whereabouts Failures" ...
#>  $ Sanction.Terms    : chr  "3-Month Suspenion" "Public Warning" "2-Year Suspension; Loss of Results" "1-Year Suspension; Loss of Results" ...
#>  $ Sanction.Announced: chr  "12/14/2023" "12/11/2023" "12/05/2023" "Original: 3/20/2023; Updated: 12/01/2023" ...

    You can also use the scrape_sanctions() function.
